PHASES OF COLLEGE LIFE.
BY MALTBIE D. BABCOCK, D. D.

The demands of scholarship were never
harder and higher than they are today. The
era of specialties is upon us. A man to count
must be an authority in his department, and
this invcdves an element of competition, as well
as concentration, unparalleled in other days.
Because of this specializing, men are apt to
underestimate the value of straight college
training uninfluenced by a professional outlook. 1 believe that college is for the whole
man rather than the specialized scholar, for the
disciplining of his mind, for the concentration
of attention, with moral as well as mental results, for the culture which puts one in touch
with the world's thoughts and achievements,
that multiplies his sympathies and widens his
horizon, that teaches a man where to find the
proper tools of intellectual life and how to use
them.
As far as possible the peril of specializing in
the college course should be avoided. To know
much of any one thing involves intentional
ignorance of a great many others. The intentional ignorance should not be too great. Here
is the function of the college in giving a foundation for a specialty. If the Washington
monument had a foundation no wider than it,
own base, it would be a perilous affair. if
you know your calling in advance, do not imperil it by a too sympathetic choice of electives
in the college years.
A broad handle of good sound wood is the
right backing of a chisel's cutting edge. A narrow handle back of a narrow edge makes a poor
combination. When Paul wrote to Timothy,
who was hardly out of his preparatory work,
Ile said : "Take heed to thyself and to the
doctrine," putting what he was, ahead of what
he knew.

Take heed to your body is a word for today.
A young man hardly knows what a tremendous
part of himself his body is and of what importance it will be in the work of later life.
Abuse it, overtax it, sin against it, underfeed,
under-exercise, or under-rest it, and you will
find that nature is a minute bookkeeper, charging every item of overdrawn money, and doing
heartless and heart-breaking work when she
forecloses. The danger of specialization has
crept into athletics. Few boilers can run more
than one large engine. Few stomachs and
nervous systems can support good scholars and
prize athletes. This is too often discovered
after graduation. The prizes are as dangerous
on the campus as in the study hall. The exercise that keeps hunger healthy, the skin active,
that breaks down and cleans out old tissue and
gives an honest physical need of sleep is enough
for the average college man. As much exercise as this a good scholar must have. If he
misses some scholastic prizes in keeping his
body in order he has made a good bargain.
So few men can be prize winners and yet keep
healthy bodies that I advise boys I know going
to college to keep shoulder high with the best
in their class rather than make the sacrifice
that is demanded to top its head by half an inch.
Of course, a man should be ashamed of himself
who lets men suspect. that he intends to be a
chiropodist by being always at the foot of his
class. To be in the nineties is hard enough
work and a high enough aim for a man who
does not plan to be a burnt offering at one
hundred on Ambition's altar. The point is not
to outpoint some competitor, but to be equipped
for your life work and fairly equal to it in body
and mind. An honest student with a healthy
body will whip the intellectual freak in the
long run.

PRESIDENT OILMAN'S NEW BOOK.

The Century Company has recently published a new work by President Gilman, entitled, University Problems in the United
States." It consists of several addresses, most
of which were delivered at other institutions,
including Harvard, Yale, Cornell and California. Perhaps the most interesting address,
to Hopkins men at least, is his inaugural, delivered at the opening of the University in
1876. He speaks of the buildings in the heart
of the city as merely temporary, until the completion of arrangements for the final establishment at Clifton. The book also contains a letter written by Dr. Gilman in response to a request for his views on the advisability of founding a national university at Washington. In
this he shows how greatly such an institution
would interfere with all the existing colleges
and universities of the East, and especially
with those in and about Washington. The plan

which he suggests is a union of the many noteworthy educational institutions of Washington
about the Smithsonian as a centre. In this
way a university would be established which
would afford the highest facilities to those
students who desire to do earnest and, in some
degree, independent work, as such an institution would have"no curriculum, no public examinations, no degrees, but abundant opportunities."

SOME, to whose words both experience and
observation should lend authority, have said
that most college men may expect to get as
much from association with their class-mates
and instructors as from actual study. If this be
true, those agencies that tend to bring college
men together are valuable and worthy of more
consideration than we sometimes give them.
Many such agencies exist here, and all have
their peculiar advantages and limitations. The
fraternities, with their intimate and enduring
fellowships are at the same time restricted to
a few, and naturally clannish. Although they
are often very helpful to the individuals who
belong to them, their influence upon college life
as a whole is of doubtful value. Other associations attract only those who pursue certain
studies.
A welcome to the sessions of the
Philological Association has little charm for
one who does not care for Greek roots. If you
do not know bugs and plants you must shun
the Naturalists' Club. If you can't tell a knight
from a rook or know the mystery of a king's
gambit, the Chess Club will bore you. Even
the Y. M. C. A., with its broad principles, is
avoided by some who fear that the secretary
may try to convert them.
Of late a new institution has been discov-

ered which has the same end as the organizations just mentioned, and lacks many of their
disadvantages. Its chief fault is its very transient character, which, unfortunately, cannot
be remedied. This promoter of good-fellowship is known by the somewhat inelegant title,
Feed." Our first experience with it was at
the opening of the cage last winter, and we
were all much gratified by the result.
That informal celebration, which it is hardly
necessary to describe here, now seems all the
more satisfactory when it is compared with a
somewhat elaborate feast held at the end of the
year in a near-by restaurant. This was planned
in honor of our athletic victories and as a farewell to the seniors. The design was good, but
the way in which it was carried out was much
to our discredit. For the sake of the reputation of the University and the self-respect of
the students, it is to be hoped that they will
never celebrate their victories in such fashion
again.
Let us make the "Athletic Feed" under our
own roof-tree a permanent thing, and future
generations will hold us in grateful recollection.

BY MALTBIE D. BABCOCK, D. D.

The demands of scholarship were never
harder and higher than they are today. The
era of specialties is upon us. A man to count
must be an authority in his department, and
this invcdves an element of competition, as well
as concentration, unparalleled in other days.
Because of this specializing, men are apt to
underestimate the value of straight college
training uninfluenced by a professional outlook. 1 believe that college is for the whole
man rather than the specialized scholar, for the
disciplining of his mind, for the concentration
of attention, with moral as well as mental results, for the culture which puts one in touch
with the world's thoughts and achievements,
that multiplies his sympathies and widens his
horizon, that teaches a man where to find the
proper tools of intellectual life and how to use
them.
As far as possible the peril of specializing in
the college course should be avoided. To know
much of any one thing involves intentional
ignorance of a great many others. The intentional ignorance should not be too great. Here
is the function of the college in giving a foundation for a specialty. If the Washington

you know your calling in advance, do not imperil it by a too sympathetic choice of electives
in the college years.
A broad handle of good sound wood is the

combination. When Paul wrote to Timothy,
who was hardly out of his preparatory work,

A young man hardly knows what a tremendous
part of himself his body is and of what importance it will be in the work of later life.
Abuse it, overtax it, sin against it, underfeed,
under-exercise, or under-rest it, and you will
find that nature is a minute bookkeeper, charging every item of overdrawn money, and doing
heartless and heart-breaking work when she
forecloses. The danger of specialization has
crept into athletics. Few boilers can run more
than one large engine. Few stomachs and
nervous systems can support good scholars and
prize athletes. This is too often discovered
after graduation. The prizes are as dangerous
on the campus as in the study hall. The exercise that keeps hunger healthy, the skin active,
that breaks down and cleans out old tissue and
gives an honest physical need of sleep is enough
for the average college man. As much exercise as this a good scholar must have. If he
misses some scholastic prizes in keeping his

PRESIDENT OILMAN'S NEW BOOK.

The Century Company has recently published a new work by President Gilman, entitled, University Problems in the United
States." It consists of several addresses, most
of which were delivered at other institutions,
including Harvard, Yale, Cornell and California. Perhaps the most interesting address,
to Hopkins men at least, is his inaugural, delivered at the opening of the University in
1876. He speaks of the buildings in the heart
of the city as merely temporary, until the completion of arrangements for the final establishment at Clifton. The book also contains a letter written by Dr. Gilman in response to a request for his views on the advisability of founding a national university at Washington. In
this he shows how greatly such an institution
would interfere with all the existing colleges
and universities of the East, and especially
with those in and about Washington. The plan

about the Smithsonian as a centre. In this
way a university would be established which
would afford the highest facilities to those
students who desire to do earnest and, in some

SOME, to whose words both experience and
observation should lend authority, have said
that most college men may expect to get as
much from association with their class-mates
and instructors as from actual study. If this be
true, those agencies that tend to bring college
men together are valuable and worthy of more
consideration than we sometimes give them.
Many such agencies exist here, and all have
their peculiar advantages and limitations. The
fraternities, with their intimate and enduring
fellowships are at the same time restricted to
a few, and naturally clannish. Although they
are often very helpful to the individuals who
belong to them, their influence upon college life
as a whole is of doubtful value. Other associations attract only those who pursue certain
studies.
A welcome to the sessions of the
Philological Association has little charm for
one who does not care for Greek roots. If you
do not know bugs and plants you must shun
the Naturalists' Club. If you can't tell a knight
from a rook or know the mystery of a king's
gambit, the Chess Club will bore you. Even
the Y. M. C. A., with its broad principles, is
avoided by some who fear that the secretary
may try to convert them.
Of late a new institution has been discov-

ered which has the same end as the organizations just mentioned, and lacks many of their
disadvantages. Its chief fault is its very transient character, which, unfortunately, cannot
be remedied. This promoter of good-fellowship is known by the somewhat inelegant title,
Feed." Our first experience with it was at
the opening of the cage last winter, and we
were all much gratified by the result.
That informal celebration, which it is hardly
necessary to describe here, now seems all the
more satisfactory when it is compared with a
somewhat elaborate feast held at the end of the
year in a near-by restaurant. This was planned
in honor of our athletic victories and as a farewell to the seniors. The design was good, but
the way in which it was carried out was much
to our discredit. For the sake of the reputation of the University and the self-respect of
the students, it is to be hoped that they will
never celebrate their victories in such fashion
again.
Let us make the "Athletic Feed" under our
own roof-tree a permanent thing, and future
generations will hold us in grateful recollection.
